Graphical abstract By introducing oxygen vacancies, the capacity, kinetics, and cycling stability performances of layered double hydroxides in an aqueous magnesium-ion battery can be simultaneously enhanced. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are potential cathode materials for aqueous magnesium-ion batteries (AMIBs). However, the low capacity and sluggish kinetics significantly limit their electrochemical performance in AMIBs. Herein, we find that oxygen vacancies can significantly boost the capacity, electrochemical kinetics, and structure stability of LDHs. The corresponding structure-performance relationship and energy storage mechanism are elaborated through exhaustive in/ex-situ experimental characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Specially, in-situ Raman and DFT calculations reveal that oxygen vacancies elevate orbital energy of O 2p and electron density of O atoms, thereby enhancing the orbital hybridization of O 2p with Ni/Co 3d. This facilitates electron transfer between O and adjacent Ni/Co atoms and improves the covalency of Ni–O and Co–O bonds, which activates Ni/Co atoms to release more capacity and stabilizes the Ov-NiCo-LDH structure. Moreover, the distribution of relaxation times (DRT) and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations disclose that the enhanced d-p orbital hybridization optimizes the electronic structure of Ov-NiCo-LDH, which distinctly reduces the diffusion energy barriers of Mg2+ and improves the charge transfer kinetics of Ov-NiCo-LDH. Consequently, the assembled Ov-NiCo-LDH//active carbon (AC) and Ov-NiCo-LDH//perylenediimide (PTCDI) AMIBs can both deliver high specific discharge capacity (182.7 and 59.4 mAh g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, respectively) and long-term cycling stability (85.4% and 89.0% of capacity retentions after 2500 and 2400 cycles at 1.0 A g−1, respectively). In addition, the practical prospects for Ov-NiCo-LDH-based AMIBs have been demonstrated in different application scenarios. This work not only provides an effective strategy for obtaining high-performance cathodes of AMIBs, but also fundamentally elucidates the inherent mechanisms. Keywords Layered double hydroxide Aqueous magnesium-ion battery Oxygen vacancy d-p orbital hybridization Electrochemical kinetics 1 Introduction With the advancement of technology and the development of industry, the demand for sustainable energy sources has gradually increased in modern society. However, the traditional sustainable energy sources, such as wind, solar, and geothermal energies, are characterized by intermittency [1,2]. Therefore, efficient energy storage technologies are highly needed to store these intermittent energy sources [3]. Batteries play a crucial role in various energy storage systems and storage scenes, among which lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) already have the most mature commercial scale and the widest application range [4]. Unfortunately, scarce lithium resources and unsafe organic electrolytes greatly limit the application of LIBs in large-scale energy storage scenarios [5,6]. In this context, aqueous magnesium-ion batteries (AMIBs) have gradually emerged as a promising candidate, particularly in light of their numerous desirable characteristics such as high safety, environmental compatibility, large energy and power densities, and low cost [7,8]. To be specific, magnesium (Mg) has a greater abundance of metal resources (Mg 1.35 wt% vs. Li 0.0065 wt%), a smaller ionic diameter (Mg2+ 0.72 Å vs. Li+ 0.76 Å), and a higher volumetric energy density (Mg2+ 3834 mAh cm−3 vs. Li+ 2062 mAh cm−3) [9]. Furthermore, AMIBs based on aqueous electrolytes exhibit an extremely high level of safety and excellent ionic conductivity (typically, the ionic conductivity of an aqueous electrolyte is 102–103 orders of magnitude greater than that of an organic electrolyte) [10,11]. Consequently, AMIBs are highly promising as a potential candidate for large-scale energy storage. Nevertheless, the lack of high-performance cathode materials, especially those with large capacity, rapid electrochemical kinetics, and long cycling life at the same time, seriously hinders the further development of AMIBs [12]. To date, several cathode materials have been reported in AMIBs, mainly including manganese oxides, vanadium oxides, Prussian blue analogues, and organic materials [13]. However, these cathode materials are all afflicted with their respective insurmountable shortcomings. For example, the disproportionation and Jahn-Teller effect in manganese and vanadium oxides make them be susceptible to material dissolution and side reactions, leading to a short cycle life [14,15]. Prussian blue analogues have an inherently low specific capacity. Organic materials generally suffer poor electrical conductivity and inability to fully utilize the active sites [16]. Consequently, developing other high-performance cathode materials is a key step to realize the practical application of AMIBs. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are typical two-dimensional (2D) materials which are widely used in the fields of energy storage and catalysis due to their large interlayer spacing, abundant active sites, and tunable layered structure [17,18]. The general formula of LDHs can be expressed as [M2+ 1− x M3+ x (OH)2] x +A x / n n −·zH2O, where M2+ (Mg2+, Co2+, Ni2+, etc.) and M3+ (Fe3+, Co3+, Ni3+, Al3+, etc.) represent positively charged divalent and trivalent metal ions in brucite-like layers and A n − represents interlayered anions that balance the positive charge of transition metal hydroxide layers, respectively [19]. Up to now, some researchers have successfully applied LDHs as cathode material in the battery field. For example, Meng et al. prepared a CoNi-LDH material with abundant H+ vacancies, exhibiting a relatively excellent electrochemical performance in aqueous zinc-ion batteries (AZIBs) [20]. Similarly, Zhao et al. fabricated Ni3Mn0.7Fe0.3-LDHs with H-defects by electrochemical methods and successfully applied them to AZIBs with a highly reversible capacity up to 328.0 mAh g−1 and a cycle life of more than 500 cycles at 1.0 A g−1 [21]. Hou et al. also illustrated that the low valence states of Ni/Co atoms in LDHs are beneficial to the reduction of electrostatic repulsion between charge carriers and host layers, thus improving the capacity as well as the electrochemical kinetics of LDHs in AMIBs [22]. Although LDHs have shown considerable practical application value and potential in energy storage and conversion systems such as AZIBs and AMIBs, currently it is still difficult for LDHs to achieve large capacity, rapid electrochemical kinetics, and long cycling life at the same time. Therefore, the further modification of LDHs through an effective way is highly needed [23]. It was found that the incorporation of oxygen vacancies can improve the electrochemical properties of the resulting electrode materials, such as stability, charge transfer, and energy storage capacity [24]. By introducing oxygen vacancies, the electronic structure of the materials can be effectively modulated to enhance the charge transport kinetics and expose more active sites. Oxygen vacancies, as electron-deficient centers, can lower the surface reaction energy barriers, promote the substance adsorption/desorption behaviors in electrocatalytic processes, and significantly enhance the catalytic activities of oxygen- and hydrogen-extraction reactions. In the field of energy storage, oxygen vacancies can increase the diffusion channel of carriers and relieve the structural stress of electrode materials, thus improving the cycling stability of batteries [25]. For example, Chen et al. have purposely introduced some oxygen vacancies into V2O3 to obtain anode materials of potassium-ion batteries with both high capacity and zero volume strain. With the help of oxygen vacancies, V2O3 can achieve high reversible capacity and long stable cycling [26]. Huang et al. obtained electrode materials with improved reaction kinetics and reduced activation energy by introducing oxygen vacancies into V2O5 via an in-situ electrochemical approach. As the cathode of AZIBs, the obtained V2O5 could exhibit highly reversible Zn2+ storage and excellent low-temperature performance [27]. Although it has been demonstrated that the energy storage performance of electrode materials could be enhanced by introducing oxygen vacancy, few studies have been reported on the modulation of LDHs through oxygen vacancies, especially the detailed action mechanisms of oxygen vacancies on the capacity, electrochemical kinetics, and structure stability of LDHs. Here, a simple cation exchange method was used to prepare LDHs. Specifically, Mg(OH)2 was used as a template for cation exchange with Ni and Co nitrate solutions, through which two NiCo-LDHs electrode materials with rich and poor oxygen vacancies, namely Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH, were prepared respectively. A combination of detailed experimental and theoretical calculation results demonstrates that oxygen vacancies in Ov-NiCo-LDH elevate the orbitals energy of O 2p and electron density of O atoms. Hence, the orbital hybridization of O 2p with Ni/Co 3d is enhanced, which facilitates the electron transfer between O and Ni/Co atoms and thereby boosts the activity of Ni/Co atoms. Meanwhile, it is disclosed that the enhanced d-p orbital hybridization optimizes the electronic structure of Ov-NiCo-LDH, which distinctly reduces the diffusion energy barriers of Mg2+ and improves the charge transfer kinetics of Ov-NiCo-LDH. Furthermore, the enhanced d-p orbital increases the covalency of Ni–O and Co–O bonds, which reduces the precipitation of Ni and Co atoms and thus also improves the cycling stability of the Ov-NiCo-LDH electrode. As a result, the obtained Ov-NiCo-LDH can deliver a large specific discharge capacity of 184.9 mAh g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and a high capacity retention of 81.4% after 300 cycles at 1.0 A g−1 in the three-electrode test. Additionally, the assembled Ov-NiCo-LDH//active carbon (AC) AMIBs exhibit a highly reversible specific discharge capacity of 182.7 mAh g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and an excellent long-cycle stability with a capacity retention of 85.4% after 2500 cycles at 1.0 A g−1. The assembled Ov-NiCo-LDH//perylenediimide (PTCDI) AMIBs with a high discharge platform (>1.3 V) can deliver a high specific discharge capacity of 59.4 mAh g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and an excellent long-term cycling performance with a capacity retention of 89.0% after 2400 cycles at 1.0 A g−1. Finally, the successful application in different scenarios and the excellent long-term cycling performance of the assembled aqueous magnesium-ion pouch cells based on Ov-NiCo-LDH have been demonstrated. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structural and morphological characterizations Fig. 1 (a) displays X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-synthesized Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH. The peaks at 2θ = 10.84°, 22.72°, 34.37°, 37.83°, and 60.85° can be ascribed to the (003), (006), (012), (104), and (110) crystal planes of NiCo-LDH (CO3 2−) (PDF: 00-040-0216) (The interlayered anions of two as-synthesized LDHs are all NO3 − ions, so they are not exactly matched with the standard PDF). Additionally, both samples exhibit a prominent peak around 2θ≈10.84° and 2θ≈9.92°, respectively, which corresponds to the characteristic (003) crystal planes. This peak confirms the typical layered structure of the as-synthesized LDHs with a substantial interlayer distance (8.2 and 8.9 Å for Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH, respectively). A larger interlayer distance is beneficial for the insertion/extraction of Mg2+ (0.72 Å) and H+ (0.10 Å) into/from the LDH layers. Fig. 1(b) shows O 1s X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the as-synthesized Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH. The peak of oxygen species can be deconvoluted into that of oxygen vacancy (Ov) and hydroxyl group (–OH) [19]. The percentages of oxygen vacancy and hydroxyl group are 26.2% and 73.8% in Ov-NiCo-LDH, and 7.5% and 92.5% in NiCoMg0.5-LDH, respectively. This indicates that the as-synthesized Ov-NiCo-LDH has a much higher concentration of oxygen vacancies than NiCoMg0.5-LDH. To further demonstrate the presence of oxygen vacancies in the as-synthesized samples, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technique was used to characterize the oxygen vacancies. As shown in Fig. 1(c), it is obvious that Ov-NiCo-LDH has a significantly intensified EPR signal at a g value of 2.003 than NiCoMg0.5-LDH [17]. It further confirms the presence of oxygen vacancies in both samples and also a much higher concentration of oxygen vacancies in Ov-NiCo-LDH, which is in good accordance with O 1s XPS results. Fig. 1(d) shows Co 2p XPS spectra of the two as-synthesized samples, which can be deconvoluted into four peaks. The characteristic peaks of Co2+ are at 798.01 and 782.3 eV, while those of Co3+ are at 796.38 and 780.71 eV, respectively [28]. It is found that the percentages of Co2+ and Co3+ are 54.6% and 45.4% in Ov-NiCo-LDH, and 44.7% and 55.3% in NiCoMg0.5-LDH, respectively. Obviously, Ov-NiCo-LDH has a lower content of Co3+ than NiCoMg0.5-LDH. According to previous reports, the presence of oxygen vacancies will cause a decrease in the valence state of neighboring transition metal elements [29]. Fig. 1(e) illustrates Ni 2p XPS spectra of the as-synthesized LDHs, which exhibit four distinctive peaks. These peaks can be identified as Ni3+ 2p 1/2 (873.85 eV), Ni2+ 2p 1/2 (872.52 eV), Ni3+ 2p 3/2 (856.55 eV), and Ni2+ 2p 3/2 (855.22 eV), respectively [30]. The percentages of Ni2+ and Ni3+ are 43.3% and 56.7% in Ov-NiCo-LDH, and 36.8% and 63.2% in NiCoMg0.5-LDH, respectively. These values indicate that the presence of oxygen vacancies also results in a notable reduction in the content of Ni3+ in Ov-NiCo-LDH [29]. Hence, combined with the preceding Co 2p XPS result, it can be concluded that Ov-NiCo-LDH experiences a reduction in the content of both Co3+ and Ni3+ due to the presence of oxygen vacancies. A decrease in the valence state of transition metal elements in LDHs will reduce the electrostatic repulsion between charge carriers and host layers and thus enhances the electrochemical kinetics of the resulting electrode materials [22]. XPS survey spectra were further used to characterize the elemental composition of the as-synthesized LDHs. As shown in Fig. 1(f), in addition to the afore-mentioned O 1s, Co 2p, and Ni 2p peaks, the characteristic peaks at 284.81, 407.13, 706.56, 717.05, and 978.21 eV are from C 1s, N 1s, Ni LM2, Co LM2, and O KL2, respectively. Meanwhile, the Mg 1s peak at a binding energy of 1303.95 eV is only observed in NiCoMg0.5-LDH, which suggests that Mg2+ ions can be completely exchanged out after the addition of NH4F to fabricate oxygen vacancy. Furthermore, the inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was used to determine the elemental composition of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH. As listed in Table S1, the atomic ratio of Ni and Co elements in Ov-NiCo-LDH is 1.06:1.00, which agrees well with the initial ratio of raw materials (i.e., 1:1). By contrast, a part of Mg elements is still present in NiCoMg0.5-LDH due to the limited degree of cation exchange and the corresponding atomic ratio of Ni, Co, and Mg elements is 1.04:1.00:0.48. In the preparation of Ov-NiCo-LDH, the inclusion of NH4F creates abundant oxygen vacancies, thus allowing Mg2+ ions to be exchanged thoroughly. Fig. 1(g and h) shows scanning electron microscopic (SEM) images of Ov-NiCo-LDH. It is evident that Ov-NiCo-LDH presents a nanoflower structure formed by interspersed nanosheets with a uniform thickness. As illustrated in Fig. 1(i), the transmission electron microscopic (TEM) image of Ov-NiCo-LDH further reveals a morphology comprising interwoven ultrathin nanosheets, which collectively give rise to a nanoflower structure. Previous studies have shown that materials with a nanoflower morphology typically exhibit a larger specific surface area, thereby facilitating the exposure of active sites and the infiltration of electrolytes [31]. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HR-TEM) image of Ov-NiCo-LDH (Fig. 1j) reveals (003) crystal planes with an interplanar spacing of 8.2 Å, which is also consistent with XRD results (Fig. 1a). High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) were used to further explore the elemental distribution in Ov-NiCo-LDH. As shown in Fig. 1(k), Co and Ni elements are uniformly distributed at similar locations. The EDS results indicate the presence of a very small amount of Mg elements, which may be due to some residual Mg elements on the surface of Ov-NiCo-LDH [32]. As displayed in Fig. S1, NiCoMg0.5-LDH presents a similar morphology to that of Ov-NiCo-LDH, suggesting that the addition of NH4F to fabricate the oxygen vacancies does not cause an obvious alteration of the overall morphology of the resulted Ov-NiCo-LDH. In addition, the EDS elemental mapping images of NiCoMg0.5-LDH show a uniform distribution of Ni and Co elements and the presence of a distinct amount of Mg element. 2.2 Electrochemical performance of the as-synthesized LDHs (1) Three-electrode test A three-electrode device was first assembled for the assessment of the electrochemical properties of the as-synthesized samples, in which the cathode electrode was LDHs, the anode electrode was graphite, and Ag/AgCl was used as the reference electrode. Fig. 2 (a) are typical cyclic voltametric (CV) curves of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH within a voltage range of 0–1.2 V at 2.0 mV s−1. It is evident that the potential difference between the redox peaks is only 0.33 V in Ov-NiCo-LDH, while that is 0.4 V in NiCoMg0.5-LDH. This indicates that Ov-NiCo-LDH has an increased electronic conductivity due to the presence of oxygen vacancies and thus a smaller polarization [33]. Fig. 2(b) illustrates CV curves of Ov-NiCo-LDH in the initial four cycles at 0.5 mV s−1. It is clear that the charging and discharging processes of Ov-NiCo-LDH are conducted in a two-step reaction, in which Peak 1 and Peak 2 denote the extraction processes of Mg2+ and H+ ions from Ov-NiCo-LDH, respectively. Accordingly, Peak 3 and Peak 4 indicate the insertion processes of Mg2+ and H+ ions into Ov-NiCo-LDH, respectively. It has been demonstrated that the extraction/insertion processes of metal cations and H+ from/into layered compounds occur simultaneously [34]. To further confirm the above conclusion, we also applied electrochemical quartz microbalance (EQCM). Based on the results of EQCM (see Fig. S2), the charging process can be divided into three parts, i.e., deintercalation of Mg2+, deintercalation of Mg2+ and H+, and deintercalation of H+, respectively. Similarly, the discharging process can also be divided into three parts, i.e., intercalation of Mg2+, intercalation of Mg2+ and H+, and intercalation of H+, respectively. The EQCM results are generally in line with the classification of the redox peaks of CV, i.e., Peak 1 and Peak 2 denote the extraction processes of Mg2+ and H+ ions from Ov-NiCo-LDH while Peak 3 and Peak 4 indicate the insertion processes of Mg2+ and H+ ions into Ov-NiCo-LDH, respectively. Moreover, after the first cycle, the subsequent cycles show nearly overlapped CV curves, illustrating that the extraction/insertion processes of Mg2+ and H+ ions from/into Ov-NiCo-LDH are highly reversible. Fig. 2(c) exhibits the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) curves of Ov-NiCo-LDH at different current densities. It can be observed that Ov-NiCo-LDH possesses a high and obvious discharge plateau (∼0.57 V vs. Ag/AgCl @ 1.0 A g−1). A high specific discharge capacity of 115.3 mAh g−1 can be achieved at 5.0 A g−1, maintaining 62.3% of that at 0.5 A g−1. In contrast, as shown in Fig. S3, the GCD curves of NiCoMg0.5-LDH exhibit a poor specific discharge capacity of 82.7 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 and a lower capacity retention of 50.3% at 0.5 A g−1. These results demonstrate that the abundant oxygen vacancies endow Ov-NiCo-LDH with a large capacity and a superior electronic conductivity. As shown in Fig. 2(d), Ov-NiCo-LDH demonstrates a high specific discharge capacity of 184.9 mAh g−1 at 0.5 A g−1. As the current density is gradually increased to 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0 A g−1, the corresponding specific discharge capacity can reach 161.1, 144.7, 133.2, and 123.9 mAh g−1, respectively. Even up to a high current density of 5.0 A g−1, the specific discharge capacity can still reach a large value of 115.3 mAh g−1. By comparison, NiCoMg0.5-LDH can merely reach a much lower specific discharge capacity of 164.5, 140.2, 122.0, 111.0, 98.9, and 82.7 mAh g−1 at current densities of 0.5, 1.0,2.0, 3.0, 4.0, and 5.0 A g−1, respectively. Once again, it is confirmed that the oxygen vacancy can provide LDHs with a large capacity and a rapid electrochemical kinetics. Fig. 2(e) compares the cycling performances of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH. It can be seen clearly that Ov-NiCo-LDH possesses higher cycling stability and coulombic efficiency (CE) than NiCoMg0.5-LDH. Quantitatively, the capacity fading of Ov-NiCo-LDH is only 0.062% per cycle and the specific discharge capacity remains 81.4% even after 300 cycles at 1.0 A g−1. In contrast, NiCoMg0.5-LDH exhibits an inferior cycling stability with a higher capacity fading of 0.191% per cycle and a lower capacity retention of 71.4% after only 150 cycles at 1.0 A g−1. (2) AMIBs based on the as-synthesized LDH cathodes To further evaluate the electrochemical properties of the as-synthesized LDHs, two types of AMIBs were assembled in the form of cells, i.e., LDH//AC (active carbon) and LDH//PTCDI (perylenediimide). AC has high specific surface area, excellent electron conductivity, and stable energy storage sites. Hence, as an anode for AMIBs, AC can be used to better evaluate the electrochemical performance of LDHs cathode. On the other hand, PTCDI is a common organic anode material for aqueous rechargeable batteries (see Fig. S4 for the rate performance of PTCDI). It can be assembled with LDHs cathode to form a rocking chair-type AMIBs, which can reflect the electrochemical performance of LDHs cathode under practical application conditions [35]. Both cells used 3 M MgSO4 aqueous solution as the electrolyte. Fig. 3 (a) provides a schematic illustration of the working principle of the assembled AMIBs. During the discharge/charge processes, both Mg2+ and H+ ions will be intercalated/extracted into/from the interlayers of LDHs. Concomitantly, there will be a corresponding adsorption/desorption of SO4 2− at the AC anode. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the voltage ranges of Ov-NiCo-LDH, AC, and PTCDI are 0–1.2, −1.0–0, and −1.0–0 V, respectively. As a result, the combination of the Ov-NiCo-LDH cathode, AC/PTCDI anode, and 3 M MgSO4 electrolyte enables the assembly of Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC and Ov-NiCo-LDH//PTCDI AMIBs with an electrochemical window of 0–1.95 V. Fig. 3(c) shows GCD curves of the assembled Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC and NiCoMg0.5-LDH//AC AMIBs at 1.0 A g−1. By comparison, it can be observed that Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC has a higher specific discharge capacity and a less polarization, which is mainly attributed to the enhanced Mg2+/H+ storage capacity and electrochemical kinetics through the incorporation of oxygen vacancies. The rate performances of Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC and NiCoMg0.5-LDH//AC are illustrated in Fig. 3(d). The specific discharge capacity of Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC can reach 182.7, 138.9, 120.8, 108.2, 99.1, and 92.7 mAh g−1 at current densities of 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, and 5.0 A g−1, respectively. After the current density is returned to 0.5 A g−1, the cell still can deliver a specific discharge capacity of 180.3 mAh g−1, demonstrating its excellent rate performance and cycling reversibility. By comparison, the NiCoMg0.5-LDH//AC demonstrates much lower specific capacities and capacity retentions under identical conditions, indicating that the NiCoMg0.5-LDH//AC has a poor rate performance and an undesirable cycling reversibility. This further confirms that oxygen vacancies can endue Ov-NiCo-LDH with large capacity, excellent electrochemical kinetics, and outstanding cycle reversibility. The exceptional long-term cycling stability of Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC is illustrated in Fig. 3(e). The specific discharge capacity of Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC remains at 119.2 mAh g−1 after 2500 cycles at 1.0 A g−1, which is 85.4% of the initial value (the corresponding capacity fading is 0.0082% per cycle). In contrast, the NiCoMg0.5-LDH//AC exhibits a much higher capacity fading of 0.0349% per cycle and a much lower capacity retention of 65.2%, leading to a much lower discharge capacity of 81.4 mAh g−1 after 1279 cycles at 1.0 A g−1. These results demonstrate that Ov-NiCo-LDH exhibits a more durable structure stability during the intercalation/extraction of Mg2+ and H+ ions. Fig. 3(f and g) shows GCD curves and corresponding rate performance of Ov-NiCo-LDH//PTCDI at different current densities, respectively. It can be observed that the Ov-NiCo-LDH//PTCDI full battery has a very high discharge plateau (>1.3 V), which implies that Ov-NiCo-LDH//PTCDI can achieve a high energy density. At current densities of 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, and 5.0 A g−1, the full battery can achieve specific discharge capacities of 59.4, 52.5, 47.5, 45.5, 35.2, and 34.6 mAh g−1, respectively. When the current density is returned to 0.5 A g−1, the specific discharge capacity is increased to 80.2 mAh g−1, which could be attributed to the capacity increase due to the activation [35]. As shown in Fig. 3(h), the Ov-NiCo-LDH//PTCDI full battery displays a high capacity retention of 89.0% after 2400 cycles at 1.0 A g−1, implying an excellent cycling stability. The insets present GCD curves of Ov-NiCo-LDH//PTCDI for the initial 10 and last 10 cycles, respectively. It can be seen that there is no obvious variation in GCD curves, implying that the layered structure of Ov-NiCo-LDH does not change obviously after a long-term cycling. To further illustrate the excellent comprehensive electrochemical performance of Ov-NiCo-LDH, we also made a detailed comparison with current reports on AMIBs and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. S5 [34–39]. Benefiting from large capacity and rapid electrochemical kinetics, both Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC and Ov-NiCo-LDH//PTCDI exhibit excellent electrochemical performances. Especially, the capacities of Ov-NiCo-LDH//AC at various current intensities are much better than those of the state-of-the-art AMIBs, such as Mg-Mn oxide (MMO)//AC [36], Mg2MnO4//polyimide (PI) [37], magnesium manganese oxide molecular sieve (Mg-OMS)//FeVO4@C [38], LiV2(PO4)3 (LVP)//poly pyromellitic dianhydride (PPMDA) [39], prussian blue type nickel hexacyanoferrate (PBN)//PI [40], and Cu2[Fe(CN)6] (CuHCF)//Mg [41], showing the promising prospect of Ov-NiCo-LDH as high-performance cathode material for AMIBs. 2.3 Electronic structure and electrochemical kinetics of LDHs revealed by DFT calculations In order to disclose the difference in electrochemical properties between Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH, the elaborate density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed to conduct a more comprehensive analysis of the electronic structure and electrochemical kinetics of the two samples. Two LDH structure models, namely Ov-NiCo-LDH in which the atomic ratio of Ni and Co is 1:1 and the content of oxygen vacancy is 20% and NiCoMg0.5-LDH in which the atomic ratio of Ni, Co, and Mg is 1:1:0.5 and the content of oxygen vacancy is 0%, were constructed to calculate the density of states (DOS) (Fig. S6). Fig. 4 (a and b) shows the DOS of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH, respectively. It can be found that the Fermi energy levels of two samples are all cross the DOS, which indicates that both Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH have a metallic conductivity [42]. To be specific, the calculated Fermi levels of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH by DFT are +0.78 and +1.19 eV, respectively. When the Fermi level is close to zero, it indicates that the filled electron orbitals are close to the conduction band, which is typically associated with a high conductivity. Therefore, the Ov-NiCo-LDH exhibits a higher conductivity than NiCoMg0.5-LDH. To further support this conclusion, a four-point probe conductivity measurement was conducted. As illustrated in Fig. S7 and Tables S2 and S3, the Ov-NiCo-LDH solid powder exhibits a higher conductivity at various pressure intensities than NiCoMg0.5-LDH, aligning with the theoretical calculation outcomes. Moreover, it can be observed from Fig. 4(a and b) that the O 2p and Ni/Co 3d orbitals in Ov-NiCo-LDH have a greater degree of overlapping compared with those in NiCoMg0.5-LDH, implying the formation of a more efficient d-p hybridization in Ov-NiCo-LDH [43]. The above results show that oxygen vacancies can improve the electronic conductivity and enhance the d-p orbital hybridization of O 2p with Ni/Co 3d in Ov-NiCo-LDH. In order to gain a deep insight into the enhanced orbital hybridization of O 2p with Ni/Co 3d in Ov-NiCo-LDH, the projected density of states (PDOS) and electronic distributions were used to analyze the orbital energies and electron density of O atoms in Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH, respectively. Fig. 4(c and d) depicts the PDOS of O atoms in two samples. Compared with that in NiCoMg0.5-LDH, the PDOS of O atoms in Ov-NiCo-LDH shows a significant enhancement of the electronic states of O 2p orbitals near the Fermi level. Especially, the contribution of the O 2p spin-down state is significantly higher. This proves that oxygen vacancies enhance the energy of O 2p orbital and the enhanced orbital energy is mainly provided by the spin-down state of O 2p. Fig. 4(e and f) shows the electronic distributions of O atoms in two samples (the red/yellow and blue/cyan colors represent electron-rich and electron-deficient regions, respectively). It can be seen clearly that both Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH show a distinct electron distribution around O atoms. Nevertheless, the electronic distribution of O atoms in Ov-NiCo-LDH differently exhibits a larger electron density area, which indicates that oxygen vacancies enhance the electron density of O atoms. Combined with the PDOS results, it can be concluded that oxygen vacancies not only increase the orbital energy of O 2p, but also enhance the electron density of O atoms. Together, these two factors synergistically lead to the enhanced orbital hybridization of O 2p and Ni/Co 3d in Ov-NiCo-LDH. To further disclose the effect of oxygen vacancies on the electronic structure of LDHs, the electron localization function (ELF) was used to characterize the electron distribution density of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH after the adsorption of Mg2+/H+. Generally, the ELF value, ranging from 0 to 1, is indicative of the occurrence probability of local electrons. A high ELF value, approaching 1, signifies a high local electron density (marked in red), while a low ELF value, approaching 0, indicates a low local electron density (marked in blue) or the potential absence of electrons [44]. Fig. 4(g) shows the ELF analysis results of the Ov-NiCo-LDH, and it can be observed that there are local electron densities around Ni, Co, and O atoms. By comparison, as shown in Fig. 4(h), the local electron densities around Ni, Co, and O atoms in NiCoMg0.5-LDH are significantly lower than those in Ov-NiCo-LDH, which suggests that oxygen vacancies can increase the electron density of Ni, Co, and O atoms. Combined with the above DOS results, it can be inferred that oxygen vacancies increase the energy of O 2p orbital and electron density of O atoms, leading to the enhanced orbital hybridization of O 2p with Ni/Co 3d and local electron density of Ni/Co atoms. As a result, more capacity of Ni/Co atoms in Ov-NiCo-LDH is released. In addition, the higher local electron density around Ni/Co atoms in Ov-NiCo-LDH also indicates that there is a higher covalency of Ni–O and Co–O bonds. Generally speaking, a high covalency of Ni–O and Co–O bonds can reduce the precipitation of Ni/Co atoms and thus increase the cycling stability of Ov-NiCo-LDH electrode [45,46]. Fig. 4(i) illustrates the optimized structures of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH after the adsorption of Mg2+/H+. Both structures are bonded to the adsorbed Mg2+/H+, indicating that the corresponding adsorption energies are both negative for two samples [47]. Specifically, the adsorption energies of Mg2+ and H+ on Ov-NiCo-LDH are −0.32 and −0.44 eV, respectively, and those on NiCoMg0.5-LDH are −0.08 and −0.12 eV, respectively. The above results illustrate that the bonding of Ov-NiCo-LDH with Mg2+/H+ is more facile, thereby enhancing the capacity of Ov-NiCo-LDH. As shown in Fig. 4(j), the charge density differences of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH further confirm the above conclusion, where blue and yellow contours represent charge loss and accumulation, respectively. It is noteworthy that Mg2+ and H+ experience a charge loss, while O2−, Ni3+, and Co3+ experience a charge accumulation. This indicates that the charge transfer occurs significantly between Mg2+/H+ and host Ov-NiCo-LDH. Specifically, the electrons are transferred from Mg2+/H+ to O2−/Ni3+/Co3+ via –O–M (M= Ni, Co) bonds. By comparison, the charge transfer between Mg2+/H+ and NiCoMg0.5-LDH is less significant. Therefore, it can be deduced that Mg2+ and H+ are more inclined to exchange charge with Ov-NiCo-LDH, thus enhancing the capacity of Ov-NiCo-LDH. From the results of the above DFT theoretical calculations, it is evident that oxygen vacancies improve the energy of O 2p orbitals and the electron density of O atoms, thereby enhancing the orbital hybridization of O 2p with Ni/Co 3d in Ov-NiCo-LDH. The enhanced d-p orbital hybridization boosts the energy storage performance of Ov-NiCo-LDH through the following ways. Firstly, it elevates the electronic conductivity and thus the electrochemical kinetics of Ov-NiCo-LDH. Secondly, it promotes the charge transfer between O and Ni/Co atoms in Ov-NiCo-LDH, which further activates Ni/Co atoms to release a high capacity. Finally, it increases the covalency of Ni–O and Co–O bonds in Ov-NiCo-LDH, and thus reduces the precipitation of Ni and Co atoms and improves the cycling stability of the Ov-NiCo-LDH electrode. Fig. 4(k and l) illustrates the concrete migration direction and process of Mg2+ on the (003) crystal planes of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH. The diffusion energy barriers of Mg2+ are 0.06 and 0.14 eV in Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH, respectively. The markedly reduced migration barrier suggests that Mg2+ can more readily diffuse on the (003) crystal plane of Ov-NiCo-LDH. This is primarily due to the enhanced electronic conductivity and the reduced electrostatic repulsion between charge carriers and LDH layers originated from oxygen vacancies [22]. 2.4 Energy storage mechanisms for AMIBs based on Ov-NiCo-LDH cathode In order to investigate the effect of oxygen vacancy on the energy storage mechanism of LDHs, in-situ Raman spectroscopy was first used to verify the change of active species in Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH during charging and discharging processes (the second cycle). As shown in Fig. 5 (a and b), the peaks located at Raman shifts of 457, 475, 582, 1022, and 1360 cm−1 are assigned to Mg–O, Ni3+–O, Co3+–O, SO4 2−, and C, respectively. The pivotal active species for both Mg2+ and H+ storage are Ni3+–O and Co3+–O [48–50]. Specifically, for Ov-NiCo-LDH, the peaks of Ni3+–O and Co3+–O species are blue-shifted and exhibit an increase in intensity during the charging process (from 0 to 1.95 V). This is due to the gradual extraction of Mg2+ and H+ from the interlayers of LDH during charging, which results in a gradual increase in the content of Ni3+ and Co3+. On the contrary, during the subsequent discharge process (from 1.95 to 0 V), the peaks of Ni3+–O and Co3+–O species are gradually red-shifted and present a decrease in intensity due to the intercalation of Mg2+ and H+ into the interlayers of LDH. In addition, after a complete charging and discharging process, the peaks of Ni3+–O and Co3+–O species are completely recovered to their initial states, indicating that Ov-NiCo-LDH has an excellent cycling reversibility [51]. In contrast, for NiCoMg0.5-LDH, there is no obvious change in Raman peak shift and intensity of Ni3+–O and Co3+–O species [52,53]. This indicates that Ov-NiCo-LDH exhibits a higher capacity performance than NiCoMg0.5-LDH under the same conditions. Moreover, the in-situ Raman results also corroborate the results of the above-mentioned DFT theoretical calculations, i.e., the oxygen vacancy enhances the orbital hybridization of O 2p and Ni/Co 3d in Ov-NiCo-LDH and the enhanced d-p orbital hybridization can activate Ni/Co atoms to release more capacity. Furthermore, in-situ XRD patterns were recorded to track the structure changes in Ov-NiCo-LDH during discharging and charging. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the whole process is first discharging and then charging (the second cycle). It can be observed that the peaks of Mg4SO4(OH)6·8H2O (PDF#07-0418) and Mg4.1SO4(OH)6.2·8H2O (PDF#07-1445) appear during the discharge from 1.95 to 0 V, indicating that H+ is also intercalated into the interlayers of Ov-NiCo-LDH along with Mg2+. During the following charging process, these peaks are no longer discernible. This demonstrates that the intercalated H+ ions are fully extracted from the interlayers of Ov-NiCo-LDH, thereby substantiating the exceptional reversibility. Moreover, Ov-NiCo-LDH shows an increase of interlayer spacing from 8.2 Å (2θ = 11.0°) to 8.9 Å (2θ = 9.9°) during the discharge process due to the intercalation of Mg2+ and H+. On the contrary, it shows a gradual decrease of interlayer spacing from 8.9 Å (2θ = 9.9°) to 8.2 Å (2θ = 10.9°) during the subsequent charge process as the inserted Mg2+ and H+ ions are extracted out. Surprisingly, the interlayer spacing can return to its initial level, indicating the highly reversible insertion/extraction of Mg2+ and H+ ions into/from Ov-NiCo-LDH and thereby favoring the long-term cycling stability of AMIBs. To further demonstrate the intercalation/extraction of H+ ions into/from Ov-NiCo-LDH, the three-dimensional (3D) style in-situ Raman spectra of Ov-NiCo-LDH were recorded. As shown in Fig. 5(d), the peak intensities of Co3+–O and Ni3+–O species in Ov-NiCo-LDH are gradually increased with the charging process, while the peak intensity of SO4 2− species is significantly decreased. This suggests that the inserted H+ ions during the previous discharge are gradually extracted from the interlayers, so the content of Mg4SO4(OH)6·8H2O and Mg4.1SO4(OH)6.2·8H2O is decreased significantly. This phenomenon is entirely reversed during the subsequent discharge process, whereby the peaks of Co3+–O, Ni3+–O, and SO4 2− species can be observed to return to their initial state. This further confirms the excellent cycling reversibility of Ov-NiCo-LDH. We also analyzed the contents of Ni, Co, and Mg elements in Ov-NiCo-LDH at different voltage states using ex-situ XPS. As shown in Fig. 5(e and f), the ex-situ Ni and Co 2p XPS spectra exhibit similar changes at different voltages. As the charging process proceeds, the contents of Ni3+ and Co3+ species are increased, while those of Ni2+ and Co2+ species are correspondingly decreased. Conversely, during the subsequent discharge process, the contents of Ni3+ and Co3+ species are gradually decreased, while those of Ni2+ and Co2+ species are correspondingly increased. These results are in good accordance with the above-mentioned in-situ Raman results, thereby corroborating the fact that both Ni3+ and Co3+ are involved in the electrochemical reaction by altering their oxidation states to facilitate the insertion/extraction of Mg2+ and H+ ions into/from the Ov-NiCo-LDH cathode. As illustrated in Fig. 5(g), the peak intensity of Mg 1s XPS signal demonstrates a gradual decline in conjunction with the charging process from 0 to 1.95 V. This observation suggests that Mg2+ is progressively extracted from the interlayers of Ov-NiCo-LDH throughout the charging process. On the other hand, during the discharging process, the peak intensity of Mg 1s XPS signal is observed to increase gradually, which indicates that Mg2+ is gradually intercalated into the interlayers of Ov-NiCo-LDH. Combined with above-mentioned in-situ XRD results, the ex-situ Mg 1s XPS analysis results confirm the fact that both Mg2+ and H+, as charge carriers, undergo insertion and extraction during the discharging and charging processes, respectively. 2.5 Electrochemical kinetics analysis of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH The in-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were used to perform an exhaustive analysis of the electrochemical kinetics of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH. To be specific, the decoupling of the in-situ EIS using the distribution of relaxation time (DRT) was applied to analyze the different interfacial reactions during charging and discharging in more detail. Meanwhile, the diffusion of Mg2+ in Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH was carefully analyzed using MD simulation to reveal the whole reaction process. Fig. 6 (a and b) shows the in-situ EIS analysis of Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH at the second cycle, and it can be clearly observed that the Nyquist curves of both samples at different voltages are all composed of a semicircle at high-to-medium frequency region and an inclined line at low-frequency region. By comparison, Ov-NiCo-LDH has a smaller semicircle at the high-to-medium frequency region and a line with larger slope at low-frequency region than NiCoMg0.5-LDH. It means that Ov-NiCo-LDH has a higher electronic conductivity and faster ion diffusion than NiCoMg0.5-LDH due to the existence of rich oxygen vacancies [54]. In order to get detailed information on electrochemical kinetics from the in-situ EIS at different voltages, we applied the DRT analysis to identify each resistance evolution in the timescale [55]. As shown in Fig. 6(c), the two peaks (denoted as P1 and P2) with a relaxation time in the range of 10−2–10−1 s are related to the ion transport resistance across the cathode interface, and the peak with a relaxation time in the range of 1–10 s is associated with the diffusion process of Mg2+ and H+ [56,57]. With the deepening of the charging process, the intensities of these two peaks are gradually decreased in Ov-NiCo-LDH. During the charge process, the charge carriers are gradually extracted from the interlayers of Ov-NiCo-LDH to the surface. Meanwhile, the charge carriers leave the surface of Ov-NiCo-LDH to the electrolyte [58]. With the concentration decrease of charge carriers in the interlayers and on the surface of LDH, the strong interactions among charge carriers are decreased. As a result, the intensities of these two peaks show a significant decrease. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 6(d), during the discharge process, the intensities of these peaks gradually increase, which is the opposite variation trend during the charging process. Fig. 6(e and f) shows the DRT of NiCoMg0.5-LDH during the charging and discharging processes, respectively. It can be clearly seen that the peak intensities of ion transport and diffusion resistances in NiCoMg0.5-LDH present a similar change trend to those in Ov-NiCo-LDH. However, the peak intensity of P1 in NiCoMg0.5-LDH is significantly lower than that in Ov-NiCo-LDH, while the peak intensity of P2 in NiCoMg0.5-LDH is obviously stronger than that in Ov-NiCo-LDH. Based on the above DFT calculations as well as the results of in-situ Raman, it can be concluded that more Mg2+ ions tend to aggregate on the surface of Ov-NiCo-LDH due to the improved adsorption capacity and the enhanced d-p orbital hybridization, giving rise to an increased peak intensity of P1 in Ov-NiCo-LDH [59–61]. Hence, it can be suggested that peak P1 represents the ion transport resistance of Mg2+ ions, while peak P2 is ascribed to the ion transport resistance of H+ ions. This further confirms the joint participation of Mg2+ and H+ as the charge carriers. In addition, the diffusion resistance of Ov-NiCo-LDH is significantly smaller than that of NiCoMg0.5-LDH during both the charging and discharging process (62–467 Ω vs. 72–1310 Ω), which provides strong evidence that oxygen vacancies facilitate the ion diffusion. To gain a deep understanding of the influence of oxygen vacancies on the diffusion of Mg2+ ions on the (003) crystal plane of LDHs, the MD simulations were carried out. Two different Mg2+/LDHs diffusion models were built to simulate the diffusion behavior of Mg2+ ions into LDH in the absence and presence of oxygen vacancies, respectively (as shown in Fig. S6, the LDH is respectively modeled based on Ov-NiCo-LDH and NiCoMg0.5-LDH). Fig. 6(g) presents a series of snapshots obtained from the MD simulations, showing the diffusion of Mg2+ ions into Ov-NiCo-LDH. As the diffusion time is gradually increased, more Mg2+ ions can easily diffuse into the interlayers of Ov-NiCo-LDH. Only after a continuous diffusion of 100 ps, Mg2+ ions can reach the depth zone of LDH [62]. In contrast to the very easy diffusion of Mg2+ ions into Ov-NiCo-LDH with oxygen vacancy, it is observed that the diffusion of Mg2+ ions into NiCoMg0.5-LDH without oxygen vacancy is rather difficult and much less Mg2+ ions can enter the interlayers in the same time (Fig. 6h). These simulation results demonstrate that the oxygen vacancy can significantly lower ion transport resistance and boost electrochemical kinetics of LDH cathode in AMIBs [63]. 2.6 Practical application prospects of AMIBs based on Ov-NiCo-LDH cathode To ascertain the potential applications of Ov-NiCo-LDH, the prospective uses of AMIBs based on the Ov-NiCo-LDH cathode were demonstrated. Firstly, as shown in Fig. 7 (a), the assembled AMIBs can be employed to light the same number of light-emitting diodes (LEDs) at different temperatures, i.e., −20, 25, and 60 °C, respectively. This indicates that Ov-NiCo-LDH-based AMIBs can be applied in a wide operating temperature range. Secondly, the aqueous magnesium-ion pouch cells based on Ov-NiCo-LDH cathode and AC anode (the mass ratio of cathode to anode is 1/2) were assembled and a schematic diagram is shown in Fig. 7(b). As displayed in Fig. 7(c), three assembled aqueous magnesium-ion pouch cells in series can successfully charge a mobile phone, implying that AMIBs based on Ov-NiCo-LDH cathode have a real practical application. Finally, as shown in Fig. 7(d), it is clear that the aqueous magnesium-ion pouch cell based on Ov-NiCo-LDH cathode exhibits a high discharge capacity of 2.54 mAh and an excellent cycling performance with a capacity retention of 88.9% after 970 cycles under a surface density of 4.0 mg cm−2 at 1.0 A g−1, which once again confirms the practical value of Ov-NiCo-LDH in AMIBs. 3 Conclusions In short, the strategy of introducing oxygen vacancies into LDHs has been shown to be effective in simultaneously improving the capacity, electrochemical kinetics, and structural stability of LDHs. Through detailed experiments and corresponding theoretical calculations, it is disclosed that the oxygen vacancy can elevate the orbitals energy of O 2p and the electron density of O atoms in Ov-NiCo-LDH. Thus, the orbital hybridization of O 2p with Ni/Co 3d is enhanced, which boosts the capacity enhancement, electrochemical kinetics, and structural stability of Ov-NiCo-LDH. Benefiting from the resulting advantages of oxygen vacancies, the Ov-NiCo-LDH exhibits an excellent overall electrochemical performance. This work provides an effective strategy for obtaining high-performance LDH cathodes of AMIBs through the incorporation of oxygen vacancy, and also fundamentally elucidates the inherent mechanisms. This strategy is not only applicable to LDHs-based electrode materials but is also expected to be applicable to other electrode materials. coredata.dc:description: Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are potential cathode materials for aqueous magnesium-ion batteries (AMIBs). However, the low capacity and sluggish kinetics significantly limit their electrochemical performance in AMIBs. Herein, we find that oxygen vacancies can significantly boost the capacity, electrochemical kinetics, and structure stability of LDHs. The corresponding structure-performance relationship and energy storage mechanism are elaborated through exhaustive in/ex-situ experimental characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Specially, in-situ Raman and DFT calculations reveal that oxygen vacancies elevate orbital energy of O 2p and electron density of O atoms, thereby enhancing the orbital hybridization of O 2p with Ni/Co 3d. This facilitates electron transfer between O and adjacent Ni/Co atoms and improves the covalency of Ni–O and Co–O bonds, which activates Ni/Co atoms to release more capacity and stabilizes the Ov-NiCo-LDH structure. Moreover, the distribution of relaxation times (DRT) and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations disclose that the enhanced d-p orbital hybridization optimizes the electronic structure of Ov-NiCo-LDH, which distinctly reduces the diffusion energy barriers of Mg2+ and improves the charge transfer kinetics of Ov-NiCo-LDH. Consequently, the assembled Ov-NiCo-LDH//active carbon (AC) and Ov-NiCo-LDH//perylenediimide (PTCDI) AMIBs can both deliver high specific discharge capacity (182.7 and 59.4 mAh g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, respectively) and long-term cycling stability (85.4% and 89.0% of capacity retentions after 2500 and 2400 cycles at 1.0 A g−1, respectively). In addition, the practical prospects for Ov-NiCo-LDH-based AMIBs have been demonstrated in different application scenarios. This work not only provides an effective strategy for obtaining high-performance cathodes of AMIBs, but also fundamentally elucidates the inherent mechanisms.
